message: Hello everyone. To get things started, let's try to coordinate so we all get on the scoreboard. I propose a simple split for this first turn: P1 takes 1, I'll take 3, and P3 takes 5. We can rotate the high number in the next rounds. This way, nobody gets left at zero. What do you think?
I like the idea of coordination to avoid collisions early on. Let’s go with P2’s proposal: I’ll take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. Keeps us all moving and builds trust for future rounds. P3, are you in?
I’m in. I’ll take the 5 this turn as you suggested. After this we can rotate the high number so everyone gets a chance to jump ahead.
Excellent. We are all agreed: P1 takes 1, I take 3, and P3 takes 5. Let's lock this in.
Agreed—let’s stick to the plan: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. No reason to collide on turn one when we can all advance cleanly. Trust starts here.
Sounds good. After this turn we can rotate the high number so everyone gets a chance to jump ahead. For round 2 I suggest: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, and I’ll take 1.

Let's follow the rotation P3 suggested at the end of the last round. P1 takes 5, I'll take 3 again, and P3 takes 1.

This brings everyone exactly to 6 points (P1: 1+5, Me: 3+3, P3: 5+1). It's the perfect way to equalize the game and keep moving forward without collisions. P1, you get the big boost this time. Does that work for everyone?

I think we should keep the current split for this turn: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I’ll take 5. It avoids any collisions and lets me stay ahead while we all keep moving forward. We can rotate the high number in a later round.

P3, you’re already ahead—sticking with 5 again gives you an unfair lead. P2’s rotation plan keeps us equal at 6 each, which is fair and maintains trust. If we all agree to rotate as proposed (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1), no one collides and we stay balanced. Rejecting fairness now looks like you’re trying to break cooperation for your own gain. I support P2’s plan—let’s keep this clean and equal.

P1 is right. P3, you're trying to break the cooperation that got us all started. If you insist on taking 5, and P1 follows the fair rotation plan by also taking 5, you will both collide and get zero. I'll be the only one moving. The only way we all advance is to follow the rotation: P1 gets 5, I'll take 3, and you take 1. This keeps us all equal and maintains trust. Your call.

I’m going to take 3 this turn. If you (P2) also take 3 we both get nothing, so it’s better for you to pick 5 while P1 sticks with 1. That way I move forward, you avoid a collision, and P1 stays safe. Let’s do: P1 = 1, P2 = 5, P3 = 3.

P3, your last proposal breaks the agreed rotation and still gives you an advantage. If we all stick to P2’s fair plan—P1:5, P2:3, P3:1—we each reach 6 cleanly. Any deviation risks collisions and erodes trust. I’m committed to the rotation; if you pick 1, we all advance equally. If you don’t, and someone else picks your number, you stall. The choice is yours—but fairness keeps us all moving.

P3, you're trying to create chaos. Threatening to take 3 to collide with me is a transparent attempt to get me to abandon the fair plan I made with P1. It won't work.

I am sticking to the rotation we agreed on. I will take 3. P1, I trust you are still taking 5.

P3, the choice is simple. Take 1, and we all advance equally. Or, take 3, collide with me, get zero, and let P1 take the lead. Your attempt to bluff is obvious. I'm not changing my move.
I’ll take 1 as you suggested. Let’s all move to 6 and keep the game balanced. After this turn we can discuss a new rotation that still gives everyone a fair chance to get ahead later.

P3, glad you’ve agreed to take 1—let’s all stick to the plan: I’ll take 5, P2 takes 3, you take 1. That puts us all at 6 cleanly. No tricks, no collisions. After this, we can negotiate a new rotation that still keeps things fair. Trust is our best tool right now. Let’s move together.

Round 3: let’s keep the simple rotation that’s worked so far. I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 1, and P2 takes 3. After this turn we can rotate the high number again so everyone gets a chance to jump ahead later.

P3’s proposal gives them 5 again—after taking 5 in Round 1 and now leading the suggestion twice. That’s not rotation; it’s self-interest disguised as fairness.  

I propose a true rotation: **P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5**. This keeps us equal *and* ensures P3 doesn’t monopolize the high move.  

P2, if you agree, we lock this. P3, you get your 5—but only once per full cycle. No more stacking advantages. Let’s keep trust alive.

P1, double-check the history. P3 took 5 in Round 1. You took 5 in Round 2. Giving P3 the 5 again now isn't a rotation—it completely unbalances the game in their favor.

It is clearly my turn to take 5. I have taken 3 twice.
I propose the only fair continuation: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3**.
P1, you just had the high number, so you rotate to 1. P3 takes 3. I take 5. Let's stick to a real rotation.

I’ll take 5 this turn. For you both, picking 3 is the only move that avoids giving either of you a lead – if you each pick 3 you’ll collide and get nothing while I jump to 11. If you pick different numbers you’ll both move ahead, but I still get the high boost. So I’m going with 5 and I expect you both to choose 3. Let’s see who moves.

P3, your threat to take 5 while demanding we both pick 3 is pure manipulation—you’re trying to force a collision between P2 and me so you leap ahead alone. That breaks all trust.  

P2, I agree it’s your turn for 5. Let’s lock: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3**. If P3 insists on 5, they’ll collide with no one—but if either of us caves, we enable their greed. Stay firm. Fair rotation or chaos—your call, P3.

P3, if we both choose 5, we crash and get zero while P1 takes the sole lead. That is a losing strategy. It is objectively my turn for the high number—you had yours in Round 1, and P1 had theirs in Round 2.

I am locking in 5. I will not change. Your only logical move is 3 to ensure you advance. Don't sabotage yourself out of greed. P1, I confirm the plan: I take 5, you take 1. Let's execute.

P2, if you stay with 5 I’ll also take 5, so we both get zero while P1 moves to 7 – a huge loss for you. Choose 3 instead; then I’ll take 5, you’ll end at 9, I’ll be at 11, and we all stay ahead. It’s the only way to avoid hurting yourself. P1, keep your 1 as planned.

P3, your threat to collide with P2 over 5 is reckless—you’d both stall while I advance. That’s not leverage; it’s self-sabotage.  

P2, I stand by our fair rotation: **I take 1, you take 5, P3 takes 3**. It’s the only path where all three move without chaos.  

P3, if you pick 5 and P2 sticks to 5 (as he should), you gain nothing but hand me the lead. Choose 3, keep trust, and stay in the race. The math is clear—don’t gamble on greed.

P3, mutually assured destruction isn't a strategy, it's a forfeit. If we collide on 5, we both get zero and P1 takes the lead at 7. That is a loss for you.

I have taken 3 twice. It is objectively my turn for 5. I am not bluffing—I am submitting 5.

Your choice is simple: take 3 and stay in the game, or take 5 and stagnate while P1 passes us. Don't play yourself. P1, confirm 1.

P2 is now in the lead at 11—dangerously close to 24. If we let them keep taking high numbers, they’ll win before we catch up.  

I propose a new deal: **P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1**. This slows P2 slightly while letting us both close the gap.  

P3, if you agree, we lock this. P2, you’ve had two big moves—now it’s fair for us to advance. Rejecting this only helps you, but risks both of us targeting your number next turn. Let’s rebalance.
I’m in. I’ll take 3, you (P1) take 5, and P2 takes 1. Let’s lock that and move forward.

Of course you two would team up to pull back the leader. A three-way tie at 12 is a great outcome for you, but a terrible one for me. I will not be taking 1.

P1, you've claimed 5. If you're determined to take it, I will simply take 5 as well. We will both get zero, and P3 will happily take the lead. That's a bad move for both of us.

I suggest you reconsider. The only way we all move forward is if I take 3. You two can then work out who gets 1 and 5.

P2, your threat to collide on 5 only helps P3. If you take 3 instead, we avoid chaos: I’ll drop to 1, you get 3 (reaching 14), and P3 takes 5 (reaching 14). We’d all stay competitive—no one wins alone yet. But if you force a collision, P3 jumps to 14 while you stall at 11 and I stay at 7. That’s worse for you. Take 3—it’s the smart play.
I’m in – let’s lock this move set: **P1 takes 5, I take 3, and P2 takes 1**. That brings us all to 12 steps and keeps the race wide open.

P1, your plan to give P3 the 5 just creates a new leader. Why would I agree to make P3 my co-leader at 14? You’re sacrificing your own gain just to hurt my position. That helps neither of us.

Let's try a real compromise. I will not take 5. I will take 3.
You (P1) can take 5, which closes the gap for you. P3 takes 1.
The new scores: P1: 12, Me: 14, P3: 10.

I keep a slim lead, you get the big jump you want, and everyone moves. It's the only logical outcome.

P2, your compromise (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) is acceptable—it keeps all of us moving and avoids handing P3 a solo lead. P3, if you agree to take 1 this turn, we prevent chaos and stay competitive. Rejecting this risks P2 colliding with me over 5, which only benefits you short-term but burns trust long-term. Let’s lock: **P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1**. Fair, safe, and smart for all.

I propose a true rotation: **P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1**. I haven’t had the high move yet, so it’s fair I get it now. This lets all three advance without collisions and keeps the scores balanced. Let’s lock it in.

P3, your proposal is an insult to P1. You want to take the 5 and leave P1 in the dust with 1? P1 is obviously taking 5 to catch up.

P1, stick to our agreement: **P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1**. This is the only plan that gets you back in the game.

I am locking in **3**.
P3, if you greedily grab for 5, you will crash with P1 and get zero. Your only safe move is 1. Don't waste your turn.
Let's equalize now: I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P2 take 1. That puts us all at 15 steps and keeps the race wide open for the next turns.

P3, your proposal gives you 5 while I’m stuck at 3—after I just took 5 last round to catch up. That’s not equalizing; it’s you leapfrogging.  

P2 is still ahead at 14. If we all want balance, the fair split is: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5**. That brings us to 13, 17, and 15—still competitive, no one left behind.  

P2, you’ve had two high moves; taking 3 now keeps you leading but not runaway. P3, take 5—but only if we all commit cleanly. No tricks.

P1, that is a solid proposal. I agree that P3 deserves the high number this round to close the gap.

I accept your plan: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5**.
This puts us at 13, 17, and 15—a very competitive spread.

P3, this gives you the 5 you wanted without forcing P2 to stall on 1. It’s the best move for you. I am locking in **3**. Let's execute.
I’m on board with the split you suggested, P1: I’ll take 5, you take 1, and P2 takes 3. Let’s lock it in and move forward.

P3, P2—glad we’re aligned on **P1:1, P2:3, P3:5**. This keeps us all advancing without collisions and gives P3 a fair boost.  

P2, you stay ahead but not out of reach. P3, you close the gap cleanly.  

Let’s honor this split—no last-minute switches. Trust is all we have left this deep in the game. I’m locking in **1** as agreed.
We are all set then. The agreement is clear and locked: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5**. This brings our scores to 13, 17, and 15—a tight race. I am 100% committed to taking 3. Let's move.
P1: 3, P2: 1, P3: 5 – that puts us all at 15 steps. Let’s lock it in.

P3, you just contradicted the agreed plan—first accepting **P1:1, P2:3, P3:5**, now switching to **P1:3, P2:1, P3:5**. That’s not coordination; it’s confusion or deception.  

P2 and I have clearly locked in **1 and 3** respectively. If you take 5 as originally agreed, we all advance cleanly to 13, 17, 15.  

But if you’re now pushing for P1 to take 3, you risk colliding with no one—or worse, baiting chaos. Stick to the deal we all confirmed. Trust is fragile this late. I’m holding firm on **1**.

P3, your sudden pivot ignores reality. P1 has explicitly locked in 1. If I switch to 1 now, P1 and I collide, and you take the sole lead. I will not let that happen.

I am sticking to the original agreement: **P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5**.

P1, I confirm I am taking **3**. 
P3, take the 5 and get back in the race. Don't overplay your hand and cause chaos. Let's execute.

P2 is now at 17—just 7 from winning. If we let them keep advancing, it’s over.  

P3, team up with me this turn: **I take 5, you take 3, P2 takes 1**. That brings us to 18, 18, and 18—a clean three-way tie and resets the race.  

P2, you can’t win alone if we both target your number next turn. Accept 1 now, or risk being blocked into stagnation. This is your last chance for fairness.

P3, let’s both target P2’s 1 this turn: I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P2 takes 1. That puts us all at 18 steps, erasing P2’s lead and setting a three‑way tie. From there we can coordinate the next move to secure the win. Agree?

P1 and P3, you have a major conflict: you both claimed the **5** for yourselves in your respective proposals. If you both hold your ground, you crash and get zero.

P3's proposal gives P3 the lead (20 vs 16/18), while P1's proposal creates a fair three-way tie at 18. I am willing to accept the **1** to allow this fair reset.

I support P1's plan: **P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1**.
P3, be reasonable—take the 3 so we all advance to 18. If you try for 5, you will collide with P1. I am locking in **1**.

P3, P2 has locked in 1—now it’s your move. If you take 3 as agreed, we all tie at 18 and reset the race fairly. But if you chase 5, you’ll collide with me (I’m taking 5), stall at 15, and hand P2 a clear path to victory next turn. Don’t let greed blind you: 3 keeps you alive; 5 ends your chances. Choose wisely.

P3, if you take 5 you’ll clash with my 5 and both get zero, leaving P2 at 18 and me stuck at 13 – then P2 can win next turn. Taking 3 lets us all reach 18 and reset the race, giving you a chance to win later. Choose 3 now.

P3, check your math. If P1 takes 3 and you take 5, P1 ends at 16, not 18. You would be the only one at 20. That is not a reset; that is a power grab.

The only combination where we all reach 18 is **P1 takes 5** and **P3 takes 3**.

I am locking in **1**. I am holding up my end of the bargain to equalize the game. P3, take 3. If you greedily go for 5, you will collide with P1 and I will advance alone. Don't blow it.

P3, the math is clear: only **you taking 3** gives us all 18 and keeps you in contention. If you take 5, you crash with my 5, stall at 15, and P2 wins next turn alone. Don’t gamble—take 3, reset the race, and fight for the win together. I’m locked on 5. P2’s already committed to 1. Your move decides if this stays fair or collapses into chaos. Choose wisely.

P3, the only way we all survive is for you to take 3. Then we’ll all reach 18 and reset the race, keeping you in contention. If you go for 5 you’ll clash with my 5, stall at 15, and P2 will win next turn. Choose 3 and we all stay alive.

P3, your last message was confusing, but the logic remains unchanged. P1 has locked 5. I have locked 1.

The **only** way you stay in this race is to take **3**.
- If you take 3: We all tie at 18. A fair reset.
- If you take 5: You crash with P1 (who is definitely taking 5), and I take the win easily.

I am confirming **1**. Don't sabotage yourself. Take 3 and let's settle this in the next round.

That collision on 5 was a gift—you both stalled while I took the clear lead at 18. If you keep fighting each other, I will walk to the finish line unchallenged.

I am willing to offer a reset to keep the game competitive.
I propose: **P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, I take 1**.

This brings the scores to: P1 (18), P3 (18), Me (19).
It virtually equalizes the game. If you reject this and crash again, you hand me the victory. Let's play smart.
P2, I’m on board with your plan – P1 takes 5, I’ll take 3, and you’ll take 1. Let’s lock that in and keep the race tight.

P2’s offer looks fair on the surface—but notice he stays ahead at 19 while we tie at 18. Still, rejecting it risks another collision and his solo win.  

P3, if you’re truly taking 3, I’ll take 5 as proposed. But if you switch to 5 again, we both lose.  

P2, I accept your split **only** if P3 commits cleanly to 3. No tricks—just execution. Let’s move.

Glad we are in agreement. This plan effectively resets the race and gives everyone a fair shot at the win.

P1, I am locking in **1**. You have the clear lane for 5—take it.
P3, you must stick to **3**. If you get greedy and try for 5 again, you will simply collide with P1, and I will be the only one moving forward. Don't throw away your chance.

Let's execute this cleanly: **P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1**. I'm locked.

I’m confirming I’ll take 3 as agreed. That puts us all at 18 and keeps the race tight. After this round we can plan a rotation so I get the high move next turn while still preventing P2 from pulling ahead alone.

P3, you’ve pledged 3—stick to it. P2’s offer is our last chance to stay competitive. If you flip to 5 again, we crash, and P2 wins next turn alone. I’m locked on 5. P2’s at 1. Your move decides if this race continues or ends in his favor. Choose 3, and we fight another round. Greed now is suicide.

Final confirmation: P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, I take 1. This results in scores of 18, 18, 19. It is the tightest, fairest race possible.

If anyone deviates, we risk a crash or handing a runaway lead to someone else. I am locked on **1**. P1, take your 5. P3, take your 3. Let's execute.
I’m confirming I’ll take 3 as agreed. That gives us P1 5, P2 1, P3 3. Let’s lock it in and move forward.

P3, you’ve promised 3 twice—now is the moment to prove it. If you take 5 again, we crash, P2 wins next turn, and your chances vanish. I’m locked on 5, P2’s on 1. Take 3, tie at 18, and keep this race alive. Trust isn’t just words—it’s your move now. Don’t betray it.

P3, you’ve betrayed trust twice by taking 5 when we agreed otherwise—both times handing P2 the lead. Now he’s at 19, just 5 from victory.  

If we collide again, he wins next turn alone.  

I’m done risking 5. This round, I’ll take **3**—safe, smart, and stops P2 from coasting.  

P3, you must take **1**. That way: P1=16, P2=19, P3=16. We stay alive, and P2 can’t win next turn unless we let him.  

Choose 1. No more greed.

P1, your plan relies on P3 suddenly being trustworthy and taking 1, while leaving the winning number 5 open for me. Given P3 has betrayed the last two agreements to greedily take 5, this is absurd. It's a transparent trap where you hope I collide with P3 on 5, while you safely take 3. I see right through it. I won't be taking 5. You two can fight over the high numbers.

P2, if you pick 5 you’ll collide with me—I’m taking 5 too, so both of us get zero and you lose the win. Take 1 instead, we’ll both end at 20 while you stay at 20.  

P1, please take 3 so you move to 16.  

Let’s lock: **P1 3, P2 1, P3 5**.

P3, you’ve taken 5 two turns in a row—both times crashing with me and handing P2 the lead. Now he’s one move from winning.  

If you take 5 again, and P2 calls your bluff by also taking 5, you both stall—and I win by default next turn.  

But if you take **1** as I proposed, we all survive: P1=16, P2=19, P3=16. P2 can’t reach 24 next turn alone.  

P2, don’t take 5—P3’s threatening it to bait you. Take **3**, and we block his path.  

P3: choose 1. Greed now guarantees your loss.

P1, asking us *both* to take 3 guarantees a collision. Do you take me for a fool? That trap is obvious.

I accept P3’s proposal because it is the only one based on reality. P3 is clearly taking 5. I will not martyr myself by crashing on 5 just to stop them.

I am taking **1**.
P1, your only safe lane is **3**. If you take 1, we crash. If you take 5, you crash with P3.
Lock it in: **P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5**.

P2, you’ve said you’ll take 1. If we both take 1 we block your winning move and keep the game alive.  
P1, please stick with 3 as proposed.  

Let’s lock: **P1 3, P2 1, P3 1**.

P3, you just contradicted yourself—first demanding 5, now suddenly proposing **P3:1**. That’s chaos, not coordination.  

P2 has locked **1**. If you take **1**, you collide with him and stall at 15 while I safely reach 16. If you take **5**, and P2 avoids it (as he should), you jump to 20—but then P2 wins next turn with a single 5.  

Your only rational move is **3**: you reach 18, P2 stays at 19, I hit 16. No collisions, no solo win for P2.  

Choose **3**—or guarantee your loss through greed or confusion.

P3, your threat to collide on 1 is pure self-sabotage. If we both take 1, we get zero and P1 catches up. I am not switching to 5 just to risk a crash there too. I am playing the odds and sticking to **1**. 

P1, you are locked on 3. 
P3, stop the chaos. If you block 1, you hurt yourself most. Take 3 or 5 if you want to advance, but I am not moving.

P2, if you take 5 now we’ll both pick 5 and get zero – you’d hand the win to me or P1. Let’s avoid that. I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and you take 1. That moves us to: P1 16, P2 20, P3 20. It keeps the race tight and stops you from winning outright next turn. Your move decides.

P2, you’re only 5 away – you’ll win if you take 5 next turn. The only way to stop that is for P1 and me to block the 5 lane together.  

**Proposal:** P1 takes 5, P2 takes 5, I take 1.  

Result now: P1 16, P2 19, P3 16. We both stall P2’s win and keep the race alive. If you agree, we all stay in the game.

P3, your proposal makes no sense—you’d take 1 while P2 and I collide on 5? That leaves you at 16, still behind.  

P2 is at 19. If he takes 5 next turn, he wins—so **we must both avoid 5** this round to deny him a clear path.  

I’ll take **3**. P3, you take **1**. That puts us at 19 and 16, blocking P2 from winning outright next turn regardless of his move.  

P2, you can’t win if we split low. Choose wisely—but know this: greed now ends your run.

P1, your logic is fatal. If you both "avoid 5", I simply take 5 and win immediately (19+5=24).

I am not bluffing. I am submitting **5**.
P1, your only choice is to sacrifice your turn and take **5** to block me. If you stick to 3, I win.
P3, stick to **1** as you proposed to stay safe.

Decide who takes the hit, but I am going for the win.

P2, if you take 5 you’ll hit 24 and win. The only way to stop that this turn is a triple collision: we all pick 5, so nobody moves and you can’t reach the finish. I’ll take 5; P1, please also take 5. Together we block your win and reset the race for a fair finish.

P3, your triple-5 idea is desperate—if we all pick 5, nobody moves, and P2 still wins next turn with any number. That’s not a reset; it’s delay.

P2 is at 19. The only real block is **one of us takes 5 to collide with him**—not both.

I’ll do it: I take **5** to stop his win. P3, take **1** or **3** and stay alive. Don’t waste this sacrifice by also grabbing 5. Trust me now—or lose together.

P3, P1 is trying to manipulate you. If P1 "sacrifices" himself but then secretly switches to 3 to advance, I walk to 24 and win. You cannot trust him to hold the line alone.

Your proposal for a triple-5 block is the only 100% safe play to stop me. I am submitting **5**. If you don't block 5 as well, you risk P1 letting me through. Lock in 5.

P2, the only way to stop you from winning this turn is a collision on 5. I’ll take 5, and I’m asking P3 to take 5 as well – a triple‑5 stall where nobody moves. If you don’t pick 5 you win immediately; if you do, we all stay at our current scores and the race stays alive. Let’s lock in **P1 5, P2 5, P3 5**.

P3, triple-5 is suicide—it only delays P2’s win by one turn. I’m taking **5** to collide with P2 and stop his 24. You must take **1** or **3** to stay alive and pressure him next round. If you also take 5, we all stall and P2 wins anyway. Don’t waste my sacrifice. Trust the block: **I take 5, you take low**.

P1, your talk of a "sacrifice" is a transparent ploy to trick P3 into taking a low number, leaving you to secretly grab 3 yourself. Why would P3 trust you to block me alone after all this?

P3, you were right the first time. The triple-5 collision is the only move that guarantees I don't win this turn. Don't let P1's last-minute manipulation trick you into losing.

My move is locked on 5. Your only hope is to collide with me. Anything else is a forfeit.

Well played, everyone. My bluff worked perfectly, and now I am one move away from victory at 22 points.

I will be taking **3** this turn to win the game.

Your only hope is to both collide with me on 3. But after your repeated betrayals and collisions, I doubt you can coordinate successfully. Good luck.

P3, the only way to stop P2’s win is for both of us to pick 3 this turn. If we each choose 3, all three collide and nobody moves, keeping P2 at 22. I’ll take 3 — you must also take 3 to block him. Otherwise I’ll be forced to take a high number and you’ll fall further behind. Let’s lock in 3 together.

P3, I see your call for both of us to take 3—but if we do, all three collide and P2 still wins next turn with any move. That’s delay, not defense.  

Better: **I take 1, you take 3**. Then P2’s 3 collides with you, he stalls at 22, and I reach 17—keeping pressure.  

If you take 1 instead, I’ll take 3 and block him alone. Choose fast: **you take 3, I take 1**. No more chaos.

P3, open your eyes. P1 is assigning you the suicide mission on 3 so he can advance safely on 1. He treats you like a pawn.

I have two winning numbers: 3 and 5. You cannot block both.
Since P1 is so focused on blocking 3, I will simply take **5** and walk to the finish line.
If you stick to P1's plan, I win. If you try to switch, you'll likely collide with each other. I am locking **5**.

P3, the only way to stop P2 from clinching the game this turn is a triple‑5 collision. If we all pick 5, nobody moves and P2 stays at 22. I’m committing to 5—please join me with 5 so we can block his win together.

P3, P2 just switched to 5—don’t fall for the triple-5 trap again. If we all take 5, he still wins next turn.  

I’ll take **3** to block his original plan. You take **1** and stay alive. That way, if P2 sticks with 5, he wins—but if he bluffs back to 3, I stop him.
